poem:
Route 42 coils through the asphalt labyrinth like an insomniac dancer.  
Its axle-thrum whispers along my spine in low, unsteady pulses.  
We pass a congregation of geese, heads bowed in slow ceremony—  
the bus glides forward, indifferent, its doors yawning shut  
against their plaintive honks.  

A wall ahead is alive with color:  
layers of spray-painted names, jagged hearts, half-shaded faces  
scrawled across cracked bricks.  
We halt mid-block, engines humming in praise,  
lingering in that moment when paint still glistens.  

Through the fogged window I taste hot asphalt rising  
from the sun-baked street, feel the city’s breath—  
the scrape of distant subway tracks, the hiss of tires turning corners  
into alleys shadowed by overhead wires.  

Inside, stale coffee hangs heavy on the air,  
a quiet anchor against the restless hum.  
I lean toward the window, fingertips tracing  
the faded route map pinned overhead: Forty-Two.  
Each dot a pulse, each line a secret vow.  

We surge ahead again, chasing the dusk,  
curving past forgotten playgrounds and shuttered storefronts.  
Neon flickers in puddles, the promise of after-hours.  
A child presses her forehead to glass, tracking our progress  
as if we carry hidden treasure.  

The engine sputters over a pothole—  
a hiccup in our onward rush—  
and I feel the bus pause,  
just long enough to drink in another splash  
of color on a vandal-kissed wall.  

Then we’re off, hurtling through city veins,  
leaving honking geese behind,  
gathering echoes of spray cans and shifting asphalt.  
Forty-Two does not ask for permission.  
It borrows the night, scatters its secrets,  
and carries us forward into tomorrow’s roar.
